data.text: HAS ANOTHER POST: Cankbrothers Eggbeaters or Candy?
I'm in the market for some new pedals Anyone have any experience of Cankbrothers eggbeaters or Candy?
I‚Äôve used them for years. Pretty decent pedal and very easy to service. Everything is replaceable too.
data.author: Brandon Joseph-David Knickerbocker

data.text: which ones do you prefer?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: Egg beaters
data.author: Brandon Joseph-David Knickerbocker

data.text: do you find the small contact area is ok? They look so tiny üòÇ
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: I‚Äôve had no issues. I‚Äôd search eBay and try finding a used pair, or your LBS might have used pair laying around that you could try.
data.author: Brandon Joseph-David Knickerbocker

data.text: Love mine - I have both. Zero issues
data.author: Dave Stinson

data.text: do you find you need stiffer shoes?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: - not at all
data.author: Dave Stinson

data.text: agree
data.author: Stephan Russell

data.text: Candy pedals are great.
data.author: Alan Stratford

data.text: Yea I use crankbrother on both of my bikes , they are brilliant, I prefer them because they have plenty of float when clipped in :-) .
data.author: Jason Collins

data.text: Yep I use them and they are great. Always takes me a bit of time to work out clipping in after a few weeks of shimano road pedal use.
data.author: Phil Johansen

data.text: Have eggbeater 3 (stainless steel body version) on RB, GB, & MB. Original eggs had seal problems. Current are better. The 3 comes w/ sleeves you can add to reduce shoe/pedal play. Reco that. Sometimes they develop spring creak, but a spritz of Boeshield T9 takes care of that. Yes, can get rebuild kit if after much use have bearing problem. I have to replace cleats maybe every 2 years (~10K miles) or so. Had one fail on a ride, retaining washer sheared letting pedal body slip off, but not bad considering I‚Äôve put somewhere North of 50,000 miles on Eggbeaters. Under flexible soles you can feel how small the pedal is, but doesn‚Äòt bother me. Under stiff soles like my gravel racing and winter shoes can‚Äòt feel pedal size.
data.author: Dave Wright

data.text: I ride eggbeaters and love them. Zero float
data.author: Shawn Severance

data.text: I don‚Äôt like them because there is very little feedback if you are in or out. Spd‚Äôs have a solid click.
data.author: Rich Wachtel

data.text: you can get 0 play cleats for them makes a big diffrence
data.author: Landi Barker

data.text: My wife has both but I ride Time, which is a similar mechanism. Anecdotally Time are generally more durable. I prefer Crankbrothers and TIme to SPD due to the simplicity of the mechanism. Been riding Time for 25 years.
data.author: Chris Andrews

data.text: are the Times single sided?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: They have a couple models that are but most double sided.
data.author: Cameron Olson

data.text: no, double. The single sided + flat versions (some Time ones may exist, very uncommon) are annoying AF despite sounding like a cool concept. Somebody gave a pair to my wife and she HATES them... the guy gave them to her hated them too.
data.author: Chris Andrews

data.text: Look
data.author: Junji Wiener

data.text: I use Eggys on my nab and Candys on my Gravel bike. 15 years and will never change
data.author: Paul Jackson

data.text: Agree. I have eggbeaters and candy's. Sometimes it takes a bit of searching to clip into the eggbeaters. Easy to service if necessary.
data.author: Derek Smith

data.text: I use Eggbeaters, Candys and even have a few bikes with Mallets. I run Stamps on my bikes that run flat pedals. I've been on them for maybe 10-15-20 years (I don't know but it's been a long time). I'll never go back to SPD.
data.author: Cat Fish

data.text: Crankrbros for the win. I have em on 3 pf 4 bikes. Do it
data.author: Dan Hocker

data.text: I use eggbeaters for road and cx, candy for gravel, and mallets for mtb. The built in float is great for my surgically repaired knee, and they work well even in snow and mud.
data.author: Jess Campbell

data.text: what do you mean by float please?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text:
https://www.cyclingweekly.com/fitness/bike-fit/should-you-have-float-in-your-cleats-255941
Should you have float in your cleats?
cyclingweekly.com
data.author: Jess Campbell

data.text: I‚Äôve been using Eggbeaters since they first came out, but switched to Candy on the gravel bike and Mallet on the MTB. A little easier to orient the pedal to clip in, and more support. Still clears mud like a champ, and a very positive engagement.
data.author: Philip Rohrer

data.text: Used to live them. Had multiple sets blow apart. Went to shimano. Never looked back.
data.author: Dave Hunt

data.text: Shimano xt, bomb proof
data.author: Justin Pare

data.text: Love mine. Best pedal for gravel imho
data.author: Stephan Russell

data.text: Had egg beaters and almost died in a mtb race once. Hauling ass hit a rock pedal broke came Un clipped!! Never again from that day forward I use XTR‚Äôs
data.author: Mike Wilson

data.text: Use em on all my bikes. Love the float for my knees. I have had two pairs break on me over the years. But I‚Äôve also had other bike parts break. You can only expect so much out of equipment.
data.author: Chris Grandjean

data.text: thanks what do you mean about float for the knees please
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: they have more ‚Äúwiggle‚Äù and ‚Äúplay‚Äù than some of the other brands. Your foot can turn small amounts without unlocking from the pedal.
data.author: Chris Grandjean

data.text: These and speedplay are the only pedals that I have been able to use without knee pain. I had some candy 2 pedals break after about 5000 miles of use. Turns out you should probably service them. Great pedals, highly recommended.
data.author: Wesley Wagner

data.text: I‚Äôve been on beaters since 2001. I currently have 2 pair of 11s on my gravel bikes and I‚Äôve had a half dozen over the years, as well as one pair of Candys. In my opinion simply, literally, the best. Easy entry and release, and the most mud resistant by far. As far as the straight beaters vs Candys unless your going to ride not clipped in or have really flexy shoes, I can‚Äôt see a reason to get the Candys. The Candys are harder to get into (only 2 sides), don‚Äôt clear mud as well, and weigh considerably more. I‚Äôve had all ‚Äúgrades‚Äù everything from the OGs up through the ranks to the titanium 11s and they all perform virtually the same although for the hefty price of $450 the 11s are the lightest pedal you can buy period. I‚Äôve never paid $450 as I don‚Äôt imagine they‚Äôre flying off the shelf at that price so they go on sale often. I just picked up a barely used pair for $225. They also make the Candys in a titanium model, as well as the Stamp (flats). But like I said performance is the same so if your not a weight weenie, cheaper ones are just fine. Some users complain that if they get a partial pedal strike and the pedal comes down on top of the rock, rather than the crank arm ‚Äúvaulting‚Äù into the rock, it can release your cleat. While it does happen on occasion it doesn‚Äôt bother me and might even be a good thing. In this photo in the sticky snot mud, with minimal fiddling my cleat clicked in with a muffled ‚Äúclick‚Äù üêç
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: #wierdbike
data.author: Dexter Rutecki

data.text: WAF!
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: my husband loves his egg beaters.
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: One more thing be sure to use the upgraded brass shoe cleats. They will wear out rather than the beater blades. I had one old set that the bars were visibly worn from a lot of use with the steal cleats. They still worked fine, but... Better to sacrifice the cleat. All of a sudden the other day my left foot would release super easy‚Ä¶ I let the cleats go too far (I‚Äôm thinking they had about 5,000 km of mostly singletrack dirt on them). Fortunaly I‚Äôve got plenty in stock (old vs new) üòâ
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Oh! That must be why Time ATAC cleats are brass! I still wore out a bunch of ATAC pedals before giving up on them. Crank Brothers never kept me in very well. I was always pulling my foot out without meaning to. I'm sure it's more because of my bad pedaling technique than something wrong with the pedals.
data.author: Rod Smith

data.text: I have Candy7s and candy11s and love them both.
data.author: Mitch Highman

data.text: Shimano or Time crank bros are junk.
data.author: Todd Brisbois

data.text: Why so?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: if you look at the design a strike from underneath will open the top of the pedal and cause a release. It happened to me, I gave away every pair I had. Shimano and Time are a safe bet. That‚Äôs just my opinion. Ride what you like. The haters will chime in, but it‚Äôs a bad design. They do make a 1 sided pedal that looks safe. I still ride Speedplay frogs, but they don‚Äôt make them anymore
data.author: Todd Brisbois

data.text: I've only ever ridden Shimano so I don't have an opinion üëç
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: I got rid of my frogs the first winter I ‚Äútried‚Äù to use them‚Ä¶
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Shimano PD-EH500 Dual for the gravel bike, OneUp aluminum pinned platform for MTB
data.author: Dave Langley

data.text: I'm also on the 'i used to own several pairs, the springs broke constantly and the cleats wear out quickly' group. OTOH I own many pairs of SPD pedals (mostly m520s) for all of my off road and utility bikes and they are super reliable.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Crank brothers are too easy to break, and have weight limits. Check out Time instead. Lots of float. I used to love Time mtb pedals, but they‚Äôve been hard to get recently, so I switched to Shimano XTR.
data.author: Lee Duncan

data.text: I used cook brothers for a while. gave them all away and went to Shimano trail SPDs, no ball of foot hot spot as with cooks. finished Unbound last year with zero foot pain (Lake MX237 being the other half of the equation).
data.author: Greg Miller

data.text: Crank Bros are absolute shit.... twice I've bent the bullshit bowtie clip mechanism badly enough to wreck the pedal and get stuck in. If you pedal with low torque and just spin like you're on a road bike, they probably work well enough but if you're putting down any real torque, especially on the upstroke, they're worthless.
data.author: Troy Browning

data.text: I‚Äôve used candy forever. They work well for me.
data.author: Rafael Vargas

data.text: As long as you service the bearings they should be fine. If you don‚Äôt, they can freeze or break.
data.author: Sean Clancy

data.text: Love them both. Eggbeaters with stiffer soled shoes, Candy when the sole is more flexible because you need the support from the small platform.
data.author: Cindy Nation

data.text: I've tried them all and always end up back on SPD. CB might have more "style" and a simple design but spd has more functionality imo. I'm on XT Enduro on the MYB and 545's on the adventure bike.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: Cool pedals and noteworthy design...This being the case, they dont hold up well. I switched to shimano pedals and I dont have to maintain pedals anymore. The most reliable eggbeater is the stainless and least expensive model. If you have to try them, that is a solid choice in my experience.
data.author: D Keith Williams
